columns.text: In this exercise, we are to determine the external financing needed to finance the sales growth of the company. We are also to determine the relationship between the EFN and the growth rate of the company and point at what growth rate the EFN equals to zero. Lastly, we are also to discuss the reasons why the internal growth rate presented in the required graph differs from the computed value.

## Pro Forma Statements
\
Pro Forma statements include a forecasted balance sheet, an income statement, and a statement of cash flows. These financial statements are necessary for the determination of the summary of projected events in the succeeding years of operation of the firm.
\
The pro forma statements are considered outputs of the financial plan. The management would estimate the projected and would then produce the pro forma statements.

## Required (1)
\
Now, let us determine the EFN using the 15\% growth rate. The following given are to be used:
 
<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Income Statement||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Sales|\$980,760|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Cost|\$792,960|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Other Expenses|\$20,060|
|$\hspace{30pt}$Earnings before income and taxes|\$167,740|
|$\hspace{30pt}$Interest Paid|\$14,740|
|$\hspace{40pt}$Taxable Income|\$153,000|
|$\hspace{40pt}$Tax Expenses (21\%)|\$32,130|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Net Income|\$120,870|
|Dividends|\$39,250|
|Addition to Retained Earnings|\$81,620|

Now, let us compute the projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes:
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before Interest \& Tax}&=\text{Projected Sales}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Cost}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Other Expenses}\\[12pt]
&={\$1,127,874}-{\$913,577.94}-{\$22,557.48}\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{\$191,738.58}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes is \$191,738.58.**

Now, let us prepare the pro forma income statement:
 
$$\textbf{Pro Forma}\\
\textbf{Income Statement}$$

$$\begin{array}{l r}
\text{Sales}&{\$1,127,874}\\
\text{Cost}&{913,577.94}\\
\text{Other Expenses}&\underline{22,557.48}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Earnings Before Interest and Taxes}&{\$191,738.58}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Interest Paid}&\underline{14,740}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxable Income}&{\$176,998.58}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxes}&\underline{37,169.70}\\
\hspace{30pt}\textbf{Net Income}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$}\textbf{139,828.88}}}\\
\end{array}$$

## Percentage of Sales Approach
\
The percentage of sales approach is a financial planning model in which the concept is to separate the accounts in the income statement and in the balance sheet into two sections- one which is directly affected by sales and the other which does not.
\
Through the sales forecast, the amount of the necessary funding is determined that will support the estimated sales of the company.

Now, let us determine the EFN using the following given for the balance sheet of the company:
 

<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Assets||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Cash|\$27,920|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Accounts Receivable|\$42,630|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Inventory|\$95,910|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Net Plant and Equipment|\$455,980|
|Liabilities and Owners' Equity||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Accounts Payable|\$71,720|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Notes Payable|\$17,620|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Long-term Debt|\$170,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Common Stock and Paid-in Surplus|\$140,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Retained Earnings|\$223,100|

Now, let us compute the total equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Equity}&=\text{Common Stock and Paid-in Surplus}\\[5pt]
&+\text{Retained Earnings}+\text{Additional Retained Earnings}\\[12pt] 
&={\$140,000}+{\$223,100}+{\$ 95,083.64}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$458,183.64}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The total equity amounts to $458,183.64.**

Now, let us compute the total debt and equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Debt and Equity}&=\text{Current Debt}+\text{Long-Term Debt}\\[5pt]
&+\text{Equity}\\[12pt] 
&={\$96,571.18}+{\$170,000}+{\$458,183.64}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$724,754.82}\\ \end{aligned}$$
 
**The total debt and equity amount to $724,754.82.**

To balance the total debt and equity and the total assets, we are to compute the external financing needed by the company:
  
$$\begin{aligned} \text{EFN}&=\text{Total Assets}-\text{Total Debt and Equity}\\[12pt] 
&={\$710,560.62}-{\$724,754.82}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$(14,194.20)}\\ \end{aligned}$$

**The external financing needed amounts to $14,194.20. The negative amount indicates that there is an excess in the financing that is available to the company.**

The table in the succeeding step indicates a change in the accounts in the balance sheet. This amount is derived by deducting the current amounts in the balance sheet from the projected amounts to determine the difference/ changes in the said amounts.

## Required (2)
\
Now, let us determine the EFN using the 20\% growth rate.

Now, let us compute the projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes:
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before Interest and Taxes}&=\text{Projected Sales}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Cost}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Other Expenses}\\[12pt]
&={\$1,176,912}-{\$953,298.72}-{\$23,538.24}\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{\$200,075.04}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes is \$200,075.04.**

Now, let us prepare the pro forma income statement:
 
$$\textbf{Pro Forma}\\
\textbf{Income Statement}$$

$$\begin{array}{l r}
\text{Sales}&{\$1,176,912}\\
\text{Cost}&{953,298.72}\\
\text{Other Expenses}&\underline{23,538.24}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Earnings Before Interest and Taxes}&{\$200,075.04}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Interest Paid}&\underline{14,740}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxable Income}&{\$189,932.04}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxes}&\underline{39,885.73}\\
\hspace{30pt}\textbf{Net Income}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$}\textbf{150,046.31}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Now, let us compute the total equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Equity}&=\text{Common Stock and Paid-in Surplus}\\[5pt]
&+\text{Retained Earnings}+\text{Additional Retained Earnings}\\[12pt] 
&={\$140,000}+{\$223,100}+{\$ 102,031.49 }\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$465,131.49 }\\ \end{aligned}$$
 
**The total equity amounts to $465,131.49 .**

Now, let us compute the total debt and equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Debt and Equity}&=\text{Current Debt}+\text{Long-Term Debt}\\[5pt]

**The total debt and equity amounts to $735,135.33 .**

To balance the total debt and equity and the total assets, we are to compute the external financing needed by the company:
  
$$\begin{aligned} \text{EFN}&=\text{Total Assets}-\text{Total Debt and Equity}\\[12pt] 
&={\$741,454.56}-{\$735,135.33}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$6,319.23}\\ \end{aligned}$$

**The external financing needed amounts to $6,319.23.**

The table in the succeeding step indicates a change in the accounts in the balance sheet. This amount is derived by deducting the current amounts in the balance sheet from the projected amounts to determine the difference/ changes in the said amounts.

## Required (3)
\
Now, let us determine the EFN using the 25\% growth rate.

Now, let us compute the projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes:
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before Interest and Taxes}&=\text{Projected Sales}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Cost}\\[5pt]
&-\text{Projected Other Expenses}\\[12pt]
&={\$1,225,950}-{\$993,019.50}-{\$24,519}\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{\$208,411.50}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The projected Earnings before Interest and Taxes is \$208,411.50.**

Now, let us prepare the pro forma income statement:
 
$$\textbf{Pro Forma}\\
\textbf{Income Statement}$$

$$\begin{array}{l r}
\text{Sales}&{\$1,225,950}\\
\text{Cost}&{993,019.50}\\
\text{Other Expenses}&\underline{24,519}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Earnings Before Interest and Taxes}&{\$208,411.50}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Interest Paid}&\underline{14,740}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxable Income}&{\$193,671.50}\\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Taxes}&\underline{40,671.02}\\
\hspace{30pt}\textbf{Net Income}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$}\textbf{153,000.48}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Now, let us compute the total equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Equity}&=\text{Common Stock and Paid-in Surplus}\\[5pt]
&+\text{Retained Earnings}+\text{Additional Retained Earnings}\\[12pt] 
&={\$140,000}+{\$223,100}+{\$ 104,040.33}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$471,140.33}\\ \end{aligned}$$
 
**The total equity amounts to $471,140.33.**

Now, let us compute the total debt and equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned} \text{Total Debt and Equity}&=\text{Current Debt}+\text{Long-Term Debt}\\[5pt]
&+\text{Equity}\\[12pt] 
&={\$103,436.50}+{\$170,000}+{\$471,140.33}\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$740,576.83}\\ \end{aligned}$$
 
**The total debt and equity amounts to $740,576.83 .**

To balance the total debt and equity and the total assets, we are to compute the external financing needed by the company:
  
$$\begin{aligned} \text{EFN}&=\text{Total Assets}-\text{Total Debt and Equity}\\[12pt] 
&={\$772,348.50}-{\$740,576.83 }\\[12pt] 
&=\boxed{\$31,771.67}\\ \end{aligned}$$

**The external financing needed amounts to \$31,771.67.**

The table in the succeeding step indicates a change in the accounts in the balance sheet. This amount is derived by deducting the current amounts in the balance sheet from the projected amounts to determine the difference/ changes in the said amounts.

Now, let us summarize the computed data as follows:
 
<center>

|Sales Growth Rates|Increase in Assets|Additional Retained Earnings|EFN|
|:--:|--:|--:|--:|
|15\%| $88,120.62 | $95,083.64 |\$(14,194.20)|
|20\%| $119,014.56 | $102,031.49 |\$6,319.23|
|25\%| $149,908.50 | $104,040.33 |\$31,771.67|

Based on the graph in the preceding step, it indicates that the sales growth and the EFN of a company are directly proportional. As the sales growth increases, the external financing needed to support the sales increases as well, and vice versa.

## Internal Growth Rate
\
The internal growth rate is referred to as the initial maximum rate of growth attainable by a company without the need for external financing. It is the rate that the company could acquire with only internal financing.

## Required (4)
\
Now, let us determine at what rate the EFN equals to zero based on the graphical presentation of the relationship between the sales growth and EFN.

Based on the graph in the preceding steps, the point to which the two lines cross is the point representing the internal growth rate. At this point, the increase in assets and the additional retained earnings is equal consequently having the EFN zero.
\
It is estimated that the internal growth rate based on the graph is greater than 15\% but significantly lesser than 20\%.

## Required (5)
\
Now, let us determine why the computed internal growth rate is different from what is determined in the graph.

## Accounting Return on Assets
\
Accounting Return on Assets is referred to as the financial measure of the company's profitability based on its assets. The ROA is computed by dividing the net income of the company by the total assets.

Now, let us compute the internal growth rate:
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Internal Growth Rate}&=\frac{\text{ROA} \times b}{1-\text{ROA}\times b}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1942\times 68\%}{1-0.1942\times 68\%}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1321}{1-0.1321}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1321}{0.8679}\times 100\\[12pt]
&={01522}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{15.22\%}\\
\end{aligned}$$
Where:
ROA= Return on Assets
*b*= Retention Ratio
 
**The internal growth rate of the company is 15.22\%.**

The computed internal growth rate using the formula given in the text determines the accurate growth rate that is used by the company, thus, the difference in the observation of the graph and the use of the formula.
